document.ModsDocTitle: Ten new species of the spider genus Althepus Thorell, 1898 from Southeast Asia (Araneae, Ochyroceratidae)
document.docAuthor: Li, Fengyuan, Liu, Chang & Li, Shuqiang
document.docTitle: Althepus cheni Li & Li, sp. n.
document.masterDocTitle: Ten new species of the spider genus Althepus Thorell, 1898 from Southeast Asia (Araneae, Ochyroceratidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Ten new species of the spider genus Althepus Thorell, 1898 from Southeast Asia (Araneae, Ochyroceratidae)

subSubSection.paragraph: Althepus cheni Li & Li sp. n. Figs 3, 4, 20, 21
Holotype: ♂, Myanmar, Kadan Island, 12°29.113'N , 98°27.786'E , 3 m a.s.l., 27.X.2017, Z. Chen. Paratypes: 1♂3♀, same data as holotype.
The specific epithet is a patronym in honour of Zhigang Chen who collected the types; noun (name) in genitive case.

Althepus cheni Li & Li, sp. n. can be distinguished from all other known species of the genus by the large, curved, spine with tip directed distally of the palpal tarsus (Figure 3A) and by the needle-like projection on the distal end of the conductor in males (Figure 3A, B); females can be distinguished by a large membranous sac extending posteriorly and by two types of spermathecae: six short, curved spermathecae, and one globose spermatheca on a long stalk on each side (Figure 4A).

caption.paragraph: Figure 3. Althepus cheni Li & Li, sp. n., male holotype. A Palp, ventral view B Palpal bulb, ventral view C Palp, prolateral view D Palp, retrolateral view. Abbreviations: CO conductor; EM embolus; CP cymbial protrusion; HS hook-shaped spine; SB serrated bristles.

Figure 4. Althepus cheni Li & Li, sp. n., male holotype and female paratype. A Internal genitalia, dorsal view B Female epigastric furrow, ventral view C Male habitus, dorsal view D Female habitus, dorsal view E Female habitus, ventral view. Abbreviation: SP spermatheca.

subSubSection.paragraph: Males: carapace 1.36-1.45 length, 1.50-1.52 width; femur I 11.22 (the number of specimens = 2; leg I lost in one specimen). Females: carapace 1.17-1.25 length, 1.26-1.38 width; femur I 7.37 (the number of specimens = 3).
Myanmar. Known only from the type locality (Figure 21).
Collected in a lowland evergreen broad-leaved forest at an altitude of 3 m.
